anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who played jason in friday the 13th the final chapter
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter is a 1984 American slasher film directed by Joseph Zito, produced by Frank Mancuso Jr., and starring Corey Feldman, Ted White, Kimberly Beck, and Crispin Glover. It is the fourth installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series. Picking up immediately after the events of "Friday the 13th Part III", the story follows a presumed-dead Jason Voorhees brought to the morgue, where he spontaneously revives and escapes. He then returns to Crystal Lake to continue his killing spree, targeting a family and a group of neighboring teenagers.\n', 'In 1984, White played hockey masked murderer Jason Voorhees in "Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter", after the director needed a large man for the part. White reluctantly accepted because he needed the money. Uneasy about playing one of the most infamous murderers in screen history, White asked not to be credited on screen for his part. He was later credited for the archive footage of him as Jason that was used in the .\n', 'On Review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, it holds a 20% approval rating based on 30 reviews, with the consensus reading: "As lumberingly single-minded as its homicidal star, "Friday the 13th - The Final Chapter" adds another rote entry to an increasingly labored franchise." Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel berated the film on their show, with the former deeming it "an immoral and reprehensible piece of trash."\n', 'Jeff is a character in "Friday the 13th Part 2" played by Bill Randolph. Jeff and girlfriend Sandra Dier (Marta Kober) visit Camp Crystal Lake in the Summer of 1984 on a counselor program. One night they go to the bedroom to have sex. Jason Vorhees enters the house and grabs a spear, he walks upstairs and enters the room where Jeff and Sandra are in bed. Sandra sees Jason and gasps but Jeff does not see him. Jason spears them both with such force that the spear goes through the bed to the floor killing them both instantly.\n', 'Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood is a 1988 American slasher film directed by John Carl Buechler and starring Lar Park Lincoln, Kevin Blair, and Susan Blu. It is the seventh installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series, and the first film with Jason Voorhees portrayed by Kane Hodder, who would continue to portray the character in three subsequent installments. The film follows a psychokinetic teenage girl who inadvertently unleashes Jason from his grave in Crystal Lake, where she and her friends are staying.\n', 'Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (stylized onscreen as Jason Lives: Friday the 13th Part VI) is a 1986 American slasher film and the sixth installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series. It was written and directed by Tom McLoughlin. Although the original concept called for Tommy Jarvis, the protagonist of "" and "", to become the new villain, the poor fan reception of "A New Beginning" prompted the producers to bring back Jason Voorhees as the series\' antagonist. In resurrecting Jason, McLoughlin made Jason an explicitly supernatural force for the first time in the series, depicting him as being raised from the dead via electricity; this version of Jason, an undead mass murderer and more powerful superhuman, would become the standard depiction for the rest of the films, until 2009\'s remake. The film likewise broke with many other series conventions, introducing metahumor and action film elements including shootouts and car chases.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Jason Lives: Friday the 13th, Part VI" (1986)\n', 'BULLET::::- 1982 "Friday the 13th Part III" as Jason Voorhees\n', 'Friday the 13th Part III (stylized onscreen as Friday the 13th Part 3: 3D) is a 1982 American slasher film directed by Steve Miner and produced by Frank Mancuso Jr. It is the third installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series and stars Dana Kimmell, Richard Brooker, Paul Kratka, Larry Zerner, and Tracie Savage. Set after the events of "Friday the 13th Part 2", the plot concerns a teenage girl and her friends on vacation at a house on Crystal Lake, where a wounded Jason Voorhees has taken refuge. The film marks the debut of antagonist Jason Voorhees wearing his signature hockey mask, which has become a trademark of both the character and the franchise, as well as an icon in American cinema and horror films in general. \n', 'BULLET::::- "Friday the 13th Part III" (1982) - Jason Voorhees hacks off a victim\'s hand before killing him\n']

5. **Integration of Information**: By consolidating information about the film's plot, character portrayal, and franchise context, the model can learn to synthesize diverse pieces of information to form a coherent understanding of complex narratives, improving its overall logical inference capabilities.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

['Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter is a 1984 American slasher film directed by Joseph Zito, produced by Frank Mancuso Jr., and starring Corey Feldman, Ted White, Kimberly Beck, and Crispin Glover. It is the fourth installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series. Picking up immediately after the events of "Friday the 13th Part III", the story follows a presumed-dead Jason Voorhees brought to the morgue, where he spontaneously revives and escapes. He then returns to Crystal Lake to continue his killing spree, targeting a family and a group of neighboring teenagers.\n', 'In 1984, White played hockey masked murderer Jason Voorhees in "Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter", after the director needed a large man for the part. White reluctantly accepted because he needed the money. Uneasy about playing one of the most infamous murderers in screen history, White asked not to be credited on screen for his part. He was later credited for the archive footage of him as Jason that was used in the .\n', 'On Review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, it holds a 20% approval rating based on 30 reviews, with the consensus reading: "As lumberingly single-minded as its homicidal star, "Friday the 13th - The Final Chapter" adds another rote entry to an increasingly labored franchise." Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel berated the film on their show, with the former deeming it "an immoral and reprehensible piece of trash."\n', 'Jeff is a character in "Friday the 13th Part 2" played by Bill Randolph. Jeff and girlfriend Sandra Dier (Marta Kober) visit Camp Crystal Lake in the Summer of 1984 on a counselor program. One night they go to the bedroom to have sex. Jason Vorhees enters the house and grabs a spear, he walks upstairs and enters the room where Jeff and Sandra are in bed. Sandra sees Jason and gasps but Jeff does not see him. Jason spears them both with such force that the spear goes through the bed to the floor killing them both instantly.\n', 'Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood is a 1988 American slasher film directed by John Carl Buechler and starring Lar Park Lincoln, Kevin Blair, and Susan Blu. It is the seventh installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series, and the first film with Jason Voorhees portrayed by Kane Hodder, who would continue to portray the character in three subsequent installments. The film follows a psychokinetic teenage girl who inadvertently unleashes Jason from his grave in Crystal Lake, where she and her friends are staying.\n', 'Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (stylized onscreen as Jason Lives: Friday the 13th Part VI) is a 1986 American slasher film and the sixth installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series. It was written and directed by Tom McLoughlin. Although the original concept called for Tommy Jarvis, the protagonist of "" and "", to become the new villain, the poor fan reception of "A New Beginning" prompted the producers to bring back Jason Voorhees as the series\' antagonist. In resurrecting Jason, McLoughlin made Jason an explicitly supernatural force for the first time in the series, depicting him as being raised from the dead via electricity; this version of Jason, an undead mass murderer and more powerful superhuman, would become the standard depiction for the rest of the films, until 2009\'s remake. The film likewise broke with many other series conventions, introducing metahumor and action film elements including shootouts and car chases.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Jason Lives: Friday the 13th, Part VI" (1986)\n', 'BULLET::::- 1982 "Friday the 13th Part III" as Jason Voorhees\n', 'Friday the 13th Part III (stylized onscreen as Friday the 13th Part 3: 3D) is a 1982 American slasher film directed by Steve Miner and produced by Frank Mancuso Jr. It is the third installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series and stars Dana Kimmell, Richard Brooker, Paul Kratka, Larry Zerner, and Tracie Savage. Set after the events of "Friday the 13th Part 2", the plot concerns a teenage girl and her friends on vacation at a house on Crystal Lake, where a wounded Jason Voorhees has taken refuge. The film marks the debut of antagonist Jason Voorhees wearing his signature hockey mask, which has become a trademark of both the character and the franchise, as well as an icon in American cinema and horror films in general. \n', 'BULLET::::- "Friday the 13th Part III" (1982) - Jason Voorhees hacks off a victim\'s hand before killing him\n']

question_info.question: who played jason in friday the 13th the final chapter
passages:
Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter is a 1984 American slasher film directed by Joseph Zito, produced by Frank Mancuso Jr., and starring Corey Feldman, Ted White, Kimberly Beck, and Crispin Glover. It is the fourth installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series. Picking up immediately after the events of "Friday the 13th Part III", the story follows a presumed-dead Jason Voorhees brought to the morgue, where he spontaneously revives and escapes. He then returns to Crystal Lake to continue his killing spree, targeting a family and a group of neighboring teenagers.
In 1984, White played hockey masked murderer Jason Voorhees in "Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter", after the director needed a large man for the part. White reluctantly accepted because he needed the money. Uneasy about playing one of the most infamous murderers in screen history, White asked not to be credited on screen for his part. He was later credited for the archive footage of him as Jason that was used in the .
On Review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, it holds a 20% approval rating based on 30 reviews, with the consensus reading: "As lumberingly single-minded as its homicidal star, "Friday the 13th - The Final Chapter" adds another rote entry to an increasingly labored franchise." Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel berated the film on their show, with the former deeming it "an immoral and reprehensible piece of trash."
Jeff is a character in "Friday the 13th Part 2" played by Bill Randolph. Jeff and girlfriend Sandra Dier (Marta Kober) visit Camp Crystal Lake in the Summer of 1984 on a counselor program. One night they go to the bedroom to have sex. Jason Vorhees enters the house and grabs a spear, he walks upstairs and enters the room where Jeff and Sandra are in bed. Sandra sees Jason and gasps but Jeff does not see him. Jason spears them both with such force that the spear goes through the bed to the floor killing them both instantly.
Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood is a 1988 American slasher film directed by John Carl Buechler and starring Lar Park Lincoln, Kevin Blair, and Susan Blu. It is the seventh installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series, and the first film with Jason Voorhees portrayed by Kane Hodder, who would continue to portray the character in three subsequent installments. The film follows a psychokinetic teenage girl who inadvertently unleashes Jason from his grave in Crystal Lake, where she and her friends are staying.
Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (stylized onscreen as Jason Lives: Friday the 13th Part VI) is a 1986 American slasher film and the sixth installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series. It was written and directed by Tom McLoughlin. Although the original concept called for Tommy Jarvis, the protagonist of "" and "", to become the new villain, the poor fan reception of "A New Beginning" prompted the producers to bring back Jason Voorhees as the series' antagonist. In resurrecting Jason, McLoughlin made Jason an explicitly supernatural force for the first time in the series, depicting him as being raised from the dead via electricity; this version of Jason, an undead mass murderer and more powerful superhuman, would become the standard depiction for the rest of the films, until 2009's remake. The film likewise broke with many other series conventions, introducing metahumor and action film elements including shootouts and car chases.
BULLET::::- "Jason Lives: Friday the 13th, Part VI" (1986)
BULLET::::- 1982 "Friday the 13th Part III" as Jason Voorhees
Friday the 13th Part III (stylized onscreen as Friday the 13th Part 3: 3D) is a 1982 American slasher film directed by Steve Miner and produced by Frank Mancuso Jr. It is the third installment in the "Friday the 13th" film series and stars Dana Kimmell, Richard Brooker, Paul Kratka, Larry Zerner, and Tracie Savage. Set after the events of "Friday the 13th Part 2", the plot concerns a teenage girl and her friends on vacation at a house on Crystal Lake, where a wounded Jason Voorhees has taken refuge. The film marks the debut of antagonist Jason Voorhees wearing his signature hockey mask, which has become a trademark of both the character and the franchise, as well as an icon in American cinema and horror films in general. 
BULLET::::- "Friday the 13th Part III" (1982) - Jason Voorhees hacks off a victim's hand before killing him
